channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Top U.S. and Russian Diplomats Discuss Possible Exchange for Griner and Whelan
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov spoke for the first time since the war began. Ukraine’s president visited the Odesa region, expressing hope that grain exports could begin soon.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Germans Tiptoe Up the Path to Energy Savings
item.description: Local leaders find themselves at the front line of Europe’s conservation efforts, fearing a Russian gas cut. It’s not an easy place to be.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: People playing in an outdoor pool in Augsburg, Germany. The city has lowered the temperature of outdoor public pools by one degree to save energy.

item.title: Why Catholicism Remains Strong in Canada
item.description: Even as Catholicism wanes in many Western countries, in Canada, it is holding steady as the largest religious denomination.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Angela Sanil, left, her sister Ashlyn, their mother Cinol and their friend Babitha Abraham came to see Pope Francis at Commonwealth Stadium, in Edmonton, Alberta. Cinol and her husband Jacob immigrated to Canada from South India in 2010. An influx of Catholic immigrants has helped the Canadian Catholic Church build up new membership.

item.title: Dr. Oh Eun-young, ‘the God of Parenting,’ Will See You Now, on TV
item.description: In South Korea, Dr. Oh Eun-young, a celebrated psychiatrist, has helped destigmatize seeking therapy and blown up the traditionally private relationship with patients by putting it all on TV.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Oh Eun-young, a specialist in child and adolescent psychiatry, is called a national hero by many South Koreans for destigmatizing language around mental health and seeking therapy.

item.title: Pressure Grows for U.A.E. to Free Asim Ghafoor, American Lawyer
item.description: Asim Ghafoor once represented the Saudi dissident and columnist Jamal Khashoggi, who was murdered in 2018 by Saudi agents. He was arrested this month in Dubai.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/ The New York Times
item.media:description: Asim Ghafoor, left, in Washington in 2008. American consular officials have been unable to reach him in recent days.

item.title: ‘Wagatha Christie’ Trial: Judge Finds No Libel
item.description: The High Court in London ruled against the plaintiff, Rebekah Vardy, putting an end to a social media feud that turned into a high-profile legal face-off.
item.dc:creator: Lou Stoppard and Katherine Rosman
item.media:description: Coleen Rooney and Wayne Rooney, the former Manchester United star, leaving the Royal Courts of Justice in London in May.

item.title: Why Pelosi’s Proposed Taiwan Visit Is Raising U.S.-China Tensions
item.description: Beijing has issued strongly worded warnings implying that China might use military force if Nancy Pelosi moves forward with a planned trip to Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi at the Capitol in January.

item.title: Deaths of Two Saudi Sisters in Australia Mystifies Police
item.description: Their bodies lay undiscovered for a month. Weeks later, the police still know little about the women or what happened to them.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Crops ‘Stored Everywhere’: Ukraine’s Harvest Piles Up
item.description: Farmers who have lived under the risk of Russian missile attacks have their doubts about an international agreement to ease a blockade on grain shipments through the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman and Diego Ibarra Sanchez

item.title: Hong Kong: Mirror Concert Accident to Be Investigated
item.description: Two dancers for the popular boy band were hospitalized, a local news outlet reported. Hong Kong officials promised an investigation.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Video on social media showed a video screen falling during Mirror’s performance at the Hong Kong Coliseum on Thursday night.

item.title: Viktor Bout Could Be Swapped for Brittney Griner. Who Is He?
item.description: Viktor Bout has been accused of supplying arms to Al Qaeda, the Taliban, and rebels in Rwanda. His exploits helped inspire a 2005 film, “Lord of War,” that starred Nicolas Cage.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Viktor Bout, a notorious Russian arms dealer, arriving at court in Bangkok in 2010. He was extradited and convicted of conspiring to kill Americans.

item.title: Iran Ramps Up Drone Exports, Signaling Global Ambitions
item.description: Tehran has quietly stepped up the sale of drone technology to countries outside the Middle East as it seeks to become a player in the international market.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Iranian Army Office, via Agence France-Presse—Getty Images
item.media:description: Drones in an underground base in Iran. Tehran has stepped up the sale of drones far from its borders, tapping into an important stream of income as sanctions cripple the economy.

item.title: Pope Francis, Slowed by Aging, Finds Lessons in Frailty
item.description: On a visit to Canada, the pontiff, 85, used his own vulnerability to demand dignity and respect for older people in a world increasingly populated by them.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Francis in Edmonton, Alberta, on Monday. The pope underwent major intestinal surgery last year and recently tore a knee ligament.

item.title: The Hunt Is On for ‘War Trophies’ in Ukraine
item.description: Collectors across the country are seeking pieces of shrapnel, bits of bombs and even the uniforms of dead Russians. It’s part of an urge to feel more directly connected to the cause.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ihor Sumliennyi, left, at a site in Ukraine hit by a Russian cruise missile as he and friends looked for artifacts from the conflict.

item.title: Breaking Agreement to Use a Condom Is a Sex Crime, Canada High Court Rules
item.description: The Supreme Court ruling is one of the strictest in a recent spate of measures addressing deceptive condom use, as courts try to define consent.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Canada’s Supreme Court has ruled that removing a condom during sexual intercourse without getting explicit permission is a crime.

item.title: Blinken and Lavrov Discuss Griner in Their First Call of the War
item.description: Ukraine said it was ready for Black Sea grain shipments to resume, while the top Russian and American diplomats talked about a prisoner swap involving the basketball star Brittney Griner.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Michael Crowley and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Russian government showing Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov during a news conference on Friday in Tashkent, Uzbekistan.

item.title: Explosion Kills Dozens of Ukrainian Captives at Russian-Held Prison
item.description: At least 50 captured fighters died in a blast at a prison in eastern Ukraine, with no clarity on exactly what happened and each country blaming the other.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Valerie Hopkins and Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: A soldier at the prison on Friday.

item.title: Three Pressing Questions About Monkeypox: Spread, Vaccination, Treatment
item.description: Containing the outbreak, scientists say, will depend on better understanding the virus’s transmission and how well available tools work.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A man receives a monkeypox vaccination at the Northwell Health Immediate Care Center at Fire Island-Cherry Grove, in New York.

item.title: Blinken and Lavrov Discuss Prisoner Swap Involving Griner and Whelan
item.description: Antony Blinken, the secretary of state, declined to say how his Russian counterpart responded as he continued to seek the release of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan, a former Marine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he spoke with Sergey V. Lavrov, his Russian counterpart, on Friday. It was their first call since Russia invaded Ukraine in February.

item.title: Lebanon Weighs Ukraine Claim That Syrian Ship Holds Stolen Grain
item.description: The Laodicea, a Syrian cargo ship, arrived in Tripoli, Lebanon, on Wednesday carrying nearly 10 tons of wheat and barley.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad

item.title: Lavrov To Propose a Time to Discuss Possible Prisoner Swap for Brittney Griner
item.description: Sergey Lavrov said he would listen to what U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken had to say about a proposal for the release of Brittney Griner and another American.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Russian Foreign Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, at a news conference in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, on Friday.

item.title: The Big Economic Question
item.description: It is not whether the U.S. is in a recession. It’s whether the economy will soon worsen.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Verónica G. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Villanueva family at a market in Alamo, Texas.

item.title: I’ll Trade You Some Cursed Baby Dolls and Metal Frogs for That Unwanted Banana Statue
item.description: John Oliver is willing to make a deal for a piece of (formerly) public art in Fitzroy. That doesn’t mean negotiations have been easy.
item.dc:creator: Besha Rodell
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: The neighborhood of Fitzroy in Melbourne, Australia. It’s quite hip.

item.title: Facing Gas Shortages, Europe Seeks to Shrink Demand for Energy
item.description: Germany may be most vulnerable to Russia’s energy squeeze, but many other countries are also facing, at minimum, high prices and restricted supples.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina, Dan Bilefsky, Erika Solomon and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: A power plant run by CEZ Group in Chorzow, Poland, in February.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A potential U.S. climate bill.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The legislation’s most immediate effect will be supercharging the growth of wind and other clean energy industries.

item.title: Why the U.S. Offered to Swap Griner for Bout, a Russian Arms Dealer
item.description: The negotiations raise questions about what, if any, standards should apply when the United States agrees to trade prisoners.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Some observers say a proposed prisoner swap of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner, right, for the arms dealer Viktor Bout would only encourage hostage taking.

item.title: There are no immediate signs of a speedy Brittney Griner deal in either Moscow or Washington.
item.dc:creator: Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: Brittney Griner in a Russian court on Wednesday. She has been detained in Russia since her arrest at an airport in February.

item.title: England Overhauls Medical Care for Transgender Youth
item.description: The National Health Service is closing England’s sole youth gender clinic, which had been criticized for long wait times and inadequate services.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi
item.media:description: The Tavistock Gender Identity Development Service in London had more than 5,000 patient referrals from 2021 to 2022.

item.title: Russia’s media regulator moves to revoke the license of Novaya Gazeta, an independent news outlet.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:description: Novaya Gazeta’s Moscow office in October. Its editor, Dmitri A. Muratov, won the Nobel Peace Prize last year.

item.title: Why a Vogue Cover Created a Controversy for Olena Zelenska
item.description: Is the magazine romanticizing war, or is the first lady weaponizing glossies?
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

item.title: Climate Change Worsened Britain’s Heat Wave, Scientists Find
item.description: Scorchers like the one last week are still unusual, but global warming is making them more likely, and worse when they do strike.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Danny Lawson/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A waterway from the Dowry Reservoir near Oldham, England, was reduced to a trickle.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden and Xi’s Fraught Phone Call
item.description: Also, U.S. G.D.P. declined again and an Australian law against foreign meddling will be tested.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik and Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: In Kharkiv, powerful missiles hit central areas and plans for the future.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian missiles struck a mechanic’s shop in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday morning, leaving debris and a tangled web of metal in its wake.

item.title: Russians, Risking Isolation in the South, Build Up for Ukrainian Attack
item.description: Russia is moving “maximum” forces to the south, which presents a role reversal from the eastern Donbas region: Ukraine is on the offensive and Russians holding a key city risk being cut off.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Maria Varenikova and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers cleaning up in front of a building hit by rockets on Thursday in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Seven Key Provisions in the Climate Deal
item.description: The $369 billion climate and tax bill would affect every aspect of U.S. energy production, with incentives for producers and consumers to move away from fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: The Block Island Wind Farm, the first commercial offshore wind farm in the U.S., in the Atlantic near Rhode Island.

item.title: A.I. Predicts the Shape of Nearly Every Protein Known to Science
item.description: DeepMind has expanded its database of microscopic biological mechanisms, hoping to accelerate research into all living things.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz

item.title: Zelensky Offers Passionate Speech for Ukraine’s Day of Statehood
item.description: Ukraine is celebrating its Day of Statehood, a holiday that both celebrates its independence and sends an unmistakable message to a neighbor with territorial ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Celebrations of Ukraine’s Day of Statehood on Thursday were mostly solemn affairs, punctuated by a passionate speech from President Volodymyr Zelensky.

item.title: Australia’s Law Against Foreign Interference Gets Test Case
item.description: A donation to a hospital led to criminal charges for an Australian of Chinese descent. The case hinges not on what he did, but on what he might have been planning to do.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: James Ross/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Di Sanh Duong in Melbourne, Australia, in 2020.

item.title: Here Are Some Prisoner Swaps That Freed Americans
item.description: The possibility of the United States exchanging basketball star Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan for a Russian prisoner is reminiscent of the deals Washington has orchestrated with Moscow and others.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: Francis Gary Powers, center, piloted a spy plane that was shot down over the Soviet Union. He was released in 1962 in a dramatic spy swap at the height of the Cold War.

item.title: ‘Wagatha Christie’ Trial Verdict Expected on Friday
item.description: A feud between two television personalities made its way to a London courtroom. A verdict is due on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Left, Daniel Leal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
item.media:description: Coleen Rooney, left, and Rebekah Vardy arrived at court in London on Thursday.

item.title: Joe Manchin and Chuck Schumer Have A Deal, for Now
item.description: Joe Manchin’s climate announcement has the potential to be a very big deal.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia.

item.title: As Brittney Griner stands trial, Moscow says there’s no deal yet on a prisoner exchange.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko, Michael Crowley and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken after a news conference in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: They Flocked to China for Boom Times. Now They’re Thinking Twice.
item.description: Global businesses and industries that rode the China growth wave for years are bracing for the fallout of a slowing economy.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A.H. Beard, a 123-year-old, family-owned mattress manufacturer in Padstow, Australia. The company sells many of its high-end mattresses in China.

item.title: Surprise Deal Would Be Most Ambitious Climate Action Undertaken by U.S.
item.description: The announcement Wednesday of an agreement in the Senate almost instantly reset the role of the United States in the global effort to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The climate legislation’s most immediate effect will be to supercharge the growth of wind and other clean energy industries in the United States, experts said.

item.title: Domestic opposition to Putin invites jail, dividing activists over the wisdom of staying put to fight.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ilya V. Yashin laying flowers at the site where the Russian opposition politician Boris Nemtsov was shot dead in 2015. Mr. Yashin himself now faces a prison sentence of up to a decade.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Brittney Griner for Viktor Bout?
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: The U.S. Senate passes a resolution seeking to label Russia as a sponsor of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bodies of civilians reportedly killed by Russian forces and wrapped in plastic in a mass grave in Bucha in April.

item.title: Britain’s Power Grid Warns of Tight Energy Supply
item.description: Unlike many European countries, Britain produces substantial amounts of its own gas, but it has still faced skyrocketing energy prices in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: A coal-fired power station in Drax, England, last year.

item.title: With Beijing and Washington at odds over Russia, China’s domestic issues hang over a Biden-Xi call.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden met virtually with President Xi Jinping of China last year.

item.title: China’s Domestic Troubles Will Hang Over Biden-Xi Call
item.description: Some American officials suspect that what is really driving China’s president to lash out recently is a desire to divert attention from his economic and pandemic problems at home.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden met virtually with President Xi Jinping of China last year.

item.title: A special military group in Germany keeps the West’s weapons flowing into Ukraine.
item.description: A little-known group at U.S. European Command in Germany fills Ukraine’s battlefield requests with donations from more than 40 countries.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military logistics specialists working in a secure attic room at the U.S. European Command headquarters in Stuttgart, Germany, are responsible for choreographing the flow of weapons and supplies into Ukraine.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. Senate Passes Semiconductor Bill
item.description: Also, Japan struggles to curb monkey attacks and Hong Kong’s leaders embrace Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: An employee wearing protective equipment pushes a cart at a semiconductor production facility for Renesas Electronics during a government organized tour for journalists in Beijing, Thursday, May 14, 2020.

item.title: U.S. Offers to Swap Arms Dealer for Griner, Whelan
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said that Washington had offered to trade Viktor Bout and that he expected to raise it soon directly with Russia’s foreign minister.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Julian E. Barnes and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Phyo Zeya Thaw, Burmese Pro-democracy Rapper, 41, Is Executed
item.description: A hip-hop star, he was a democracy activist in Myanmar and then a lawmaker. After a military coup, he joined the resistance and was hanged for it.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: U Phyo Zeya Thaw led one of Myanmar’s first hip-hop groups, which created the soundtrack for pro-democracy demonstrations. He was later elected to Parliament.

item.title: Macron criticizes the ‘hypocrisy’ of some African leaders on the Ukraine war.
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, visiting West Africa, said some countries had failed to condemn Russia’s invasion of Ukraine because of “diplomatic pressures.”
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron leaving the Presidential Palace in Yaoundé, Cameroon, on Tuesday.

item.title: Protesters Storm Iraqi Parliament
item.description: No lawmakers were present when the demonstrators, who were mostly followers of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, were in the building.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Supporters of Iraqi Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr entered the Iraqi Parliament on Wednesday with little resistance from security forces in the building.

item.title: H.I.V. Infections Remain Persistently High, U.N. Reports
item.description: More than 1.5 million people worldwide, many of them young girls, were infected amid pandemic disruptions in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A street vendor in Caracas, Venezuela, receiving rapid H.I.V. tests in December. Roughly 650,000 people died of AIDS last year, according to the U.N.

item.title: Senior European Parliament Member Targeted as Spyware Abuse Spreads
item.description: The attempted hack of a Greek opposition leader is the first aimed at a European Parliament member to be detected, but he has plenty of company among politicians, journalists and dissidents.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Nikos Androulakis filed a lawsuit in Athens to try to get authorities there to investigate an attempt to hack his phone.

item.title: U.K. Tourist Jailed for Taking Artifacts in Iraq Has Conviction Overturned
item.description: A British retiree who had been sentenced to 15 years in prison for pocketing stones and shards at an archaeological site was acquitted on appeal.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: James Fitton, center left, arriving at a Baghdad courthouse in May. In June, he was convicted of trying to smuggle antiquities while his fellow tourist Volker Waldmann, center right, was acquitted.

item.title: Bangladesh Seeks I.M.F. Loan as Inflation Rocks South Asia
item.description: As trade deficits widen, governments in the region struggle to import increasingly expensive diesel, gasoline and cooking gas.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A street market in Dhaka, Bangladesh. High inflation connected to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is being felt all over the world.

item.title: Ukraine Hits Kherson Bridge; Russia Steps Up Missile Strikes
item.description: The bridge is a critical part of Russia’s resupply route for the forces charged with holding the port city.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Antonivsky bridge on Wednesday after it reportedly came under fire in the Russian-controlled city of Kherson, Ukraine.

item.title: Anti-U.N. Protests in Congo Leave 15 Dead, Including 3 Peacekeepers
item.description: Demonstrators have accused international forces of failing to deter armed groups responsible for a wave of deadly attacks.
item.dc:creator: Steve Wembi and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.media:description: Protesters outside the United Nations base in Goma, Democratic Republic of Congo, on Monday.
